title: Should You Take Digestive Enzymes for IBS?

content: If you have irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), you may get the sense that your digestion doesn’t work properly. Eating a meal might send you running to the bathroom, doubled over in pain, or have you blown up like a balloon. While food isn’t a trigger for everyone with IBS, it’s a common complaint that can be helped by certain over-the-counter remedies. Digestive enzyme supplements are one such option widely marketed for the digestively troubled. But do they work for IBS? The answer is: sometimes.
Understanding IBS

IBS is known as a disorder of the gut-brain axis. This means there’s an irregularity in how the gut and brain communicate to express physical sensations such as pain. While the digestive tract will look structurally normal inside, there can be inappropriate muscle contractions and hypersensitivity in response to various stimulants, such as certain foods.
The Role of Digestive Enzymes

Digestive enzymes are proteins that our bodies make to break down food into absorbable nutrients. Enzymes have specific roles that target protein, sugars, fat, or carbohydrates. An enzyme works exclusively on its designated nutrient, so a protein-digesting enzyme won’t work on fat, and a sugar-digesting enzyme won’t work on protein. Therefore, an enzyme supplement can only be beneficial if it’s used to target the specific food that’s causing your digestive distress.

sections.heading: When Enzymes Are Lacking
content: A deficiency in a digestive enzyme leads to poor absorption of the nutrient it’s responsible for. Eating the nutrient will increase fluid and gas production in the gut and may cause uncomfortable symptoms.

Enzyme deficiencies can happen from conditions like pancreatic insufficiency, untreated celiac disease, or active Crohn’s disease. Yet some people naturally produce low levels of certain enzymes, leading to dietary intolerance. Lactose intolerance, a deficiency in the lactase enzyme, is the most famous due to its widespread prevalence. Less commonly, sucrose intolerance and fructose intolerance arise from deficiencies in the enzymes that target these sugars as well.
Enzyme Insufficiency and IBS
It’s important to know that IBS does not cause enzyme deficiencies. However, those with IBS who also have an enzyme deficiency may be more sensitive to the effects of malabsorption.

content: Fortunately, many enzyme deficiencies can be tested for and diagnosed. Some conditions, such as sucrose intolerance and pancreatic insufficiency, will require prescription enzymes for treatment, while others can be managed with over-the-counter products, such as lactase for lactose intolerance and xylose isomerase for fructose intolerance.

content: For a known deficiency, enzyme supplementation is an effective treatment to avoid diet restriction and a helpful tool to avoid worsening symptoms of IBS.
Enzymes for Problem Foods

Multiple nutrients can trigger IBS symptoms regardless of an identifiable enzyme deficiency. These include digestively challenging foods, which may provoke an exaggerated response in those with IBS. While some foods may fare better with the help of an enzyme, others are unlikely to feel different.
FODMAPs

Several common IBS triggers are known as “FODMAPS,” which are natural sugars found in a variety of plant foods and dairy. FODMAPS include lactose (e.g., select milk products) and fructose (e.g., honey and various fruits), as well as fructans (e.g., wheat, onion, garlic), galactooligosaccharides (e.g., beans, chickpeas, Brussels sprouts), and polyols (e.g., apples, mushrooms, celery).

FODMAPs are poorly absorbed in everyone, but certain types may feel unbearable with IBS. Fortunately, enzyme supplements are available for multiple individual FODMAP categories such as lactose, fructose, and galactooligosaccharides. Some products combine these enzymes into one dose and hold promising results for those with FODMAP hypersensitivity.

sections.heading: Fat and Fiber
content: Additional potential triggers for IBS include very oily, greasy, or fried foods, as well voluminous forms of “roughage” fiber. Unfortunately, enzyme supplements are unlikely to help here since symptoms may not be related to enzyme action. Instead they may be from too much stimulation in the gut. While there’s a very small amount of evidence that suggests that lipase, the enzyme that breaks down fat, may be helpful for those with IBS, more research is needed to prove this. Luckily, other tools are available to help with symptoms and can be addressed with your doctor or dietitian.
Key Takeaways

Digestive enzyme supplements may be helpful for managing your IBS symptoms, but only if they’re correctly matched with the trigger food. Although IBS doesn’t cause enzyme deficiencies, an existing enzyme deficiency can worsen IBS symptoms. For those sensitive to FODMAPS, targeted enzyme supplements may prevent symptoms. It’s essential to approach supplements with a critical eye and avoid those that contain unnecessary ingredients that don’t target your specific dietary issue.
